lines.text: Aren't the police a dirty lot, hobnobbing with British soldiers!
I heard that, Maureen Cassidy!
You were meant to, Constable O'Connor!
Good morning. Blowy day?
Yes, Corporal - it's the wind!
Only want to be friendly, kids.
Then go back to London, and write us a letter!
I don't come from London, love.
Go anyway.
I don't know what's the matter with youngsters in this town. Their talk is filthy, their doings are secret, and cruelty for fun.
Unemployment is the matter with them, Father Hugh. It's the deliberate policy for the British government that Irish youngsters shall corrupt in idleness.
It's time you married Rosy. It's time she got a house of her own to clean, floors to scrub.
My princess isn't interested in fellows, Father.
Your "princess" has got fellows enough in here
[taps head]
And fellas running loose in there will do a girl more damage than a barracks full of drunk dragoons.
Well, if it's one of that lot that's fit for her, Father, maybe you'll point him out!

[talking about the Easter Rebellion]
If the Germans had an ounce of sense, they'd send us guns to use against the British!
That's treason you're talking.
And friends that are listening surely to God!
Good luck to all Irishmen.
Bad luck to the British. Success to the Germans! And -
[British soldiers enter the bar]
And a very good morning to you, Corporal!

[having encountered Rosy walking alone on the beach]
Have you nothin' to do?
Precisely that!
Well, Miss Precisely, that's a pity! Doin' nothin's a dangerous occupation!

[Corporal is reading a newspaper article about fighting in France]
It seems the Jerries are giving your brave lads out there a terrible scrimmage, then.
Aye.
Well, you see Tom, Jerry's a tougher proposition than unarmed Irish children.
As far as I know, Mr. McCardle, no children were killed!
[laughs of disbelief]
All right, there were. They get you in this uniform, you aim your gun where you're told to point it, and you pull the trigger. And so does Jerry... and so would you!

[as Rosy walks out of the store]
The way I see it, Mrs. Kenyan. There's loose women and there's whores... and, then, there's British soldier's whores!
Well, if it's all the same to you, sir, I'll be straight off. I've given myself leave.
Yes?
Embarkation leave. France. Second Batallion, Southeast Lanchasires... they're in the front line. Will you tell me something, man to man? What's it like, really - front line?
[Doryan's face expresses discomfort]

Aye. Well, I'll find out soon enough. I'm a coward, you see. No, I always have been - from being a lad. I can't master it. Well, I don't suppose I've tried, really. I'd give my left arm to have a touch of what you've got. I hate it! Just the bloody thought of it gives me the shakes. In fact, that's my nightmare, the shakes. I don't mind dying - not if it's quick. Life's not that much, is it? I wouldn't mind having a gammy leg, like you've got - though I don't suppose it's funny. But the shakes? Shellshock? Just shaking and shambling like a... epileptic baby? Nay, I'd rather be dead! I can see what's coming - I'm going to disgrace myself...
You don't know what you'll do. No one does - you don't know what you're doing?
Really? I read what you did in the newspapers. That weren't no flash in the pan - you'd do the same again, I dare say.
You'd be wrong.
Well, you've done your bit - someone else's turn, eh?

[Collins has come across the townspeople tormenting Michael]
What am I to do with you? What?
Actually, it's only a bit of fun, Father.
Are you brainless, Maureen Cassidy, or what? Fun. Devil take me if the lot of you's not possessed and damned!

[meeting Doryan for the first time]
Now, I can't just say you're welcome - not in your official function. Ah, but in YOURSELF, you're welcome! A brave man is a brave man in any uniform, be it English khaki, Irish green, aye, or German gray.

[Rose has professed her love to Charles]
Rose, you're mistaking a penny mirror for the sun - do you not see that?
I see you always digging a low pit for yourself - when you should be standing on a heap of pride.
You coming in here and saying what you did just now is the only cause I've ever had for pride.

[after O'Leary has been arrested]
Is there anything you want?
Cigarette.
[Corporal gives him a cigarette]
Anything else?
Yes...
[drags on cigarette]
GET OUT OF MY COUNTRY!
God bless you, Tim O'Leary!
Talk. This whole cursed country will capsize with talk!

[about to inform on O'Leary's men]
Oh God, why have you done this to me?

[after disposing of a cart with a shipment of weapons]
Some fine pair of gun runners we are!

[the town has turned out to punish Rosy as an informer]
But why must it be Rosy?
Because she was fornicating with the fellow!

It's not a hangin' matter to be young... but it maybe should be a hangin' matter for a - man of middle age - to - try and steal the youth from a young girl. Especially, a man like me and a - girl like you. You were meant for the wide world, Rose. Not this place, not this. Me - I was born for it. It wouldn't do, Rose. I just know it wouldn't.
So, you - you don't want me, then?

[Leans to kiss Rose]
Don't want you? Oh...
[They embrace]

[Collins strikes McCardle after the mob strips Rosy]
You're taking advantage of your cloth, Father!
That's what it's for.

[to O'Keefe, after the townspeople have turned out to help retrieve the weapons]
You know, we made speeches about these people - but, by God!

[to Ryan]
Thanks. You're a man!
It will make me a different person, won't it?
Marriage?
No, the satisfaction of the flesh.
Well, that's a gate I've not been through, myself. But, no, it won't make you a different person.
I want it to.
Child, what are you expecting?
[Look up at noisy seagulls flying above]
Wings, is it?
Don't nurse your dreams, Rosy. You can't help having them, but don't nurse them. Because if you nurse your dreams, they tend to come true.

[to Doryan]
There's no local crumpet. It's married or virgin here, you know. And that priest down there's got eyes in the back of his head.

[the day after her head was shorn by the angry townsfolk]
You're being very nice to me this morning.
And when was I ever not nice to you?
[first lines]
Give it over, Michael. Thanks.
[last lines]

Charles? I think you have it in your mind that you and Rosy ought to part. Yeh, I thought as much. Well, maybe you're right and maybe you aren't but I doubt it. And that's my parting gift to you. That doubt.

[closes bus door]
God bless.
[bus drives away]
I don't know. I don't know at all. Come on, Michael.
What do you do, Rose, moonin' about all day by yourself?
You enjoyed yourself in Dublin, then?
Well, I did and I didn't. A conference of village school teachers, you know, is not exactly a...
Bacchanalia?
Bacchanalia, precisely.
In what way, precisely, was she - stimulatin'?
Why don't you see, Rose, I only taught you about Byron and Beethoven and Captain Blood. I'm not one of them fellows, me self.
I'm not daft, you know.
But, you're terribly young.

[Explaining why God ordains the sacrament of marriage]
And thirdly, for the satisfaction of the flesh. Are you scared of that?
Yes.
It should be nothing to be scared of Rosy. A function of the body.
I suppose all girls is a bit scared before.
Oh, and fellas too.
Yes?
You're a wonderful girl, Rose.
No. No, I'm not.
Of course he's a snob. Isn't that what the English is famous for?
You always think the best of people, don't you?
Why not?
Where have you been?
Ridin' - with Major Doryan.
You're bold as brass! You think that's a suitable connection for a decent Irish wife?
I think that is for my - husband to say, Father.

[Sarcastically]
Bustin' at the seams with innocence!
